title: How to Build Saunas

steps.headline: Choose a spot for your home sauna where plumbing, heating and electricity are easily accessible.
steps.description: Clear a space that is removed from overhanging trees and running water.

steps.headline: Install any necessary pipes, wires, or gas lines.
Dig a space for rocks if you are using lava rocks to heat your sauna.
This should be a simple structure consisting of wooden boards.
steps.description: Leave room for three ventilation points: one in the ceiling, one on the floor, and one above the heater. Add spaces for benches and windows as desired.

steps.headline: Insulate the inner frame with fiberglass and add a vapor barrier to keep moisture off the fiberglass and help it last longer.
Build a simple outer wall about a foot (or 30 cm) outside the inner frame.
Roof the sauna with simple wood or tile and remember to keep a ventilation spot open for steam to escape.
Install your heating system, following instructions given with the system, and leave a wide space for the sauna heater.
Place the first layer of flooring using ceramic tile.
steps.description: This goes over your heating system and will collect moisture.

steps.headline: Lay a second layer of flooring using unsecured boards.
steps.description: You should be able to easily remove these and clean the tiles.

steps.headline: Add any benches, windows and other fixtures as desired.
Test the sauna by turning on the heating system and observing the functioning of the ventilation points before using.

tyn: Access to plumbing, heat, and electricity lines

Choose a spot for your home sauna where plumbing, heating and electricity are easily accessible. Clear a space that is removed from overhanging trees and running water. Install any necessary pipes, wires, or gas lines. Dig a space for rocks if you are using lava rocks to heat your sauna. If using infrared heating, make sure you have enough power for the heating system.
